<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc431114162"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=center><B>INTRODUCTION</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>International Barrier Technology Inc. is organized under the laws of British Columbia, Canada. &nbsp;In this Annual Report, the &#147;Company&#148;, &#147;Barrier&#148;, &#147;we&#148;, &#147;our&#148; and &#147;us&#148; refer to International Barrier Technology Inc. and its subsidiaries (unless the context otherwise requires). &nbsp;We refer you to the actual corporate documents for more complete information than may be contained in this Annual Report. &nbsp;Our principal corporate offices are located at 510 4th Street North, Watkins, Minnesota, USA 55389. &nbsp;Our telephone number is 320-764-5797.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><B>BUSINESS OF INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>International Barrier Technology Inc. develops, manufactures, and markets proprietary fire resistant building materials designed to help protect people and property from the destruction of fire. &nbsp;The Company uses a patented, non-combustible, non-toxic <I>Pyrotite&#174;</I> formulation that is used to coat wood panels and has potential application to engineered wood products, paint, plastics, and expanded polystyrene. &nbsp;Sales have been US$9.5 million and US$8.4 million during Fiscal 2016 and 2015, respectively. &nbsp;During the respective reporting periods, License Fee Royalties were US$88 thousand and US $38 thousand.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><B>FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>In this Annual Report, unless otherwise specified, all dollar amounts are expressed in U.S. Dollars (&#147;$&#148;).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<A NAME="_Toc431114163"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-size:12pt" align=center><B>PART I</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B>ITEM 1. &nbsp;BUSINESS</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>1.A. &nbsp;General Development of Business</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><U>Introduction</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>International Barrier Technology Inc. and its subsidiaries are collectively hereinafter referred to as the &#147;Company&#148;.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Incorporated in July 1986, pursuant to agreements, the Company acquired the rights to the Pyrotite&#174; Technology for Canada in July 1986 and for the United States in March 1992. &nbsp;The Canadian rights and the US rights under the 1992 agreement were voluntarily terminated in January 1996 due to marketing conflict with a corporation which acquired the licensor&#146;s rights to the technology. &nbsp;A new agreement for the rights in the United States was signed in January 1996 and revised in March 1996. &nbsp;The Company acquired the world-wide rights to the Pyrotite&#174; technology, including: US patents; foreign patent filings; manufacturing know-how; trade secrets, and trademarks pursuant to a March 2004 agreement. &nbsp;The Company completed construction of a new manufacturing facility in Minnesota, USA in December 1995; the facility was upgraded to include substantial automation, increased capacity and product quality in April/May 2000; as Barrier continued to achieve double digit growth year after year, it decided the current manufacturing facility needed to be expanded. &nbsp;The planning and development of a higher volume and more fully automated facility began in 2004; the first phase that included the building addition was complete in March 2005. &nbsp;The second phase of the new line development was complete in August 2005 and the first commercial production run was in March 2006. &nbsp;The final phase of equipment installation, shake down improvements, and training was complete in late 2006 at which time full commercial production began.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company has been involved in the development and manufacturing/marketing of fire-rated building products since 1986, including current products: Pyrotite&#174;, a fire-barrier material comprised of the patented formulation reinforced with chopped fiberglass strands and applied adhered directly to structural sheathing (OSB &#150; oriented strand board or plywood) designed to prevent ignition and inhibit the spread of flames. &nbsp;The products are currently marketed through exclusive supply agreements as LP&#174; FlameBlock&#174; Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing into Residential Roof Deck, Wall Assembly, Wildland Urban Interface Zones, and Structurally Insulated Panel market; and Blazeguard<SUP>&#174;</SUP> FR Deck Panel into the Commercial Modular Market. &nbsp;In August 2015, LP and Barrier extended their existing Supply Agreement through December 31, 2019. LP is the largest producer of Oriented Strand Board (OSB) in the world and believes that Barrier&#146;s Pyrotite&#174; Technology will help them achieve their strategy of providing a number of value added OSB products to the building community. &nbsp;The agreement gives LP the exclusive right to sell Pyrotite&#174; treated panel products in North America, in all markets other than Commercial Modular, under their brand name LP&#174; FlameBlock&#174; Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing. &nbsp;During the 2014 fiscal year, the Company granted a license for the manufacture and distribution of Pyrotite&#174; products in a plant in the European Union and Russia. &nbsp;The agreement contemplates the Licensee developing additional production facilities over the term of the license. &nbsp;<A NAME="OLE_LINK1"></A><A NAME="OLE_LINK3"></A>In August 2015, the Company granted a license to LP for the manufacture and distribution of Pyrotite<SUP>&#174;</SUP> products in a plant in Clarke County Alabama. &nbsp;The Clarke County Alabama facility is targeted to be operational later in 2016. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>1.B. &nbsp;Financial Information About Segments</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Refer to the audited financial statements for Fiscal 2016 ended June 30th (footnote #10 &#147;Segmented Information and Sales Concentration&#148;) for this information.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>1.C. &nbsp;Narrative Description of Business</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>International Barrier Technology Inc. (Barrier) manufactures and sells fire-rated building materials in the United States. &nbsp;Barrier has a patented fire protective material (Pyrotite&#174;) that is applied to building materials to greatly improve their respective fire resistant properties. Coated wood panel products are sold to builders through building product distribution companies all over the United States. &nbsp;Many of the top multifamily homebuilders in the US utilize Barrier&#146;s fire-rated structural panel manufactured with Pyrotite&#174; in areas where the building code requires the use of a fire-rated building panel.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier sells LP&#174; FlameBlock Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing to LP&#174; Building Products and sales to LP accounted for 77% of Fiscal 2016 revenues. &nbsp;Barrier sells Blazeguard FR Deck Panel to ABC Supply Company (parent company of Mule-Hide Products, Inc.) and sales to the commercial modular market accounted for 23% of Fiscal 2016 revenues. &nbsp;Barrier sold LP&#174; FlameBlock Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing to LP&#174; Building Products and sales to LP accounted for 73% of Fiscal 2015 revenues. &nbsp;Barrier sold MuleHide FR Deck Panel to MuleHide Products, Inc. (who sold to ABC Supply, Co.) and sales to MuleHide accounted for 27% of Fiscal 2015 revenues.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>5</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify>Barrier&#146;s business is based on the premise that building projects occasionally require fire resistive performance. &nbsp;Whether based on a requirement of a national or local building code, the possibility for lower insurance rates, or simply the desire for safety by a building owner, Barrier&#146;s health as a manufacturing company is based on a demand for resistive building products. &nbsp;Any factor that could mitigate the demand for fire resistive construction could have a negative impact on Barrier.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier suffers a larger risk in the possibility that a new generation of technology that will impart fire resistance to building products may be developed. &nbsp;New technology may serve to decrease the demand for Barrier&#146;s Pyrotite&#174; products if the new technology proved to impart either better characteristics of fire performance or was found to be less expensive to produce and market than products manufactured with Pyrotite&#174;. &nbsp;Barrier&#146;s management team makes a concerted effort to stay abreast of new technologies as they are being developed. &nbsp;Barrier does this by staying in close contact with the industry via trade associations (e.g. The National Association of Home Builders, NAHB) and the independent research laboratories that are asked to test these new technologies and products as they are developed. &nbsp;However, there is no guarantee that the Company is able to adopt and utilize the new technology. &nbsp;New technologies require years of testing, not only in development but in use, before they are accepted and &#147;evaluated for use&#148; by the major building code agencies such as The International Code Council (ICC).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier presumes that corporate growth will be funded from positive cash flow, conventional bank loans, and from the occasional sale of equity to generate needed capital. &nbsp;The business plan anticipates stable sales volumes at the MN plant as production levels are approaching capacity limitations. &nbsp;However, Barrier anticipates growth in Pyrotite products in the marketplace when the new LP plant in the southeastern US ramps up production over the next few years. &nbsp;Companies experiencing rapid growth depend upon solid support both in the market place and in the manufacturing facilities themselves. &nbsp;Ensuring that capital is available to increase production capacity and to provide support materials and training in the market place is essential to success.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>R&amp;D activity continues to focus on developing and improving the designs of existing 1 and 2-hr certified interior and exterior wall assemblies. New R&amp;D projects were launched during the current fiscal year to examine the development of fire-rated engineered wood products (EWP), including I-joist and Rimboard. &nbsp;With the expanded use of EWP in building applications, as an alternative to solid sawn lumber, the importance of evaluating their performance during a fire has escalated tremendously. &nbsp;Efforts to develop fire-rated EWP are at an early stage, however, largely because building code requirements and the acceptance criteria for evaluating performance and suitability are still being developed. &nbsp;During the 2015 fiscal year, a new UL certified fire-rated I-Joist listing was secured, with further testing successfully completed during the 2016 fiscal year. Also during the 2016 fiscal year, LP announced the debut of LP&#174; FlameBlock&#174; I-Joist along with marketing efforts to concentrated market areas. &nbsp;Barrier feels there is great opportunity here, and will continue to pursue techniques to fire treat EWP with our Pyrotite&#174; Technology as the current year progresses. During the 2015 fiscal year, Barrier applied for and was granted a provisional patent for treating I-Joists with Pyrotite<SUP>&#174;</SUP>. &nbsp;During the year ended June 30, 2016, the Company incurred research and development costs of $41,644 (2015: $30,356).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Seasonality</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The building products industry in the United States does experience seasonality with housing starts generally depressed in winter months. &nbsp;Barrier&#146;s Pyrotite&#174; products, however, are sold in housing markets that have excellent winter business, including the states of Georgia, Texas, Florida and California. &nbsp;Also, much of the modular housing, including the foam core panel market, performs a considerable amount of their required construction inside factories. Since the work is done within protected environments they tend to be less impacted by the winter season than typical building projects. &nbsp;Seasonality, therefore, is not considered to be a major impediment to Barrier&#146;s success in the US market place.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Dependency upon Patents/Licenses/Processes</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Pursuant to an agreement for sale of technology dated 3/1/2004 (&#147;original agreement&#148;), between the Company and Pyrotite Corporation, the Company acquired the rights (previously licensed) to certain fire retardant technology and trademarks for $1,000,000. &nbsp;These rights and technology included all of the patents that deal with &#147;surface applied&#148; and &#147;integral&#148; OSB technology Pyrotite&#174; technology. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier utilizes patented manufacturing technology, as well as manufacturing know-how and trade secrets that have been developed and are closely protected by Barrier.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The manufacturing process for the Pyrotite&#174; products is protected by trade secrets and has a patent on an improved technology. &nbsp;International Barrier Technology, Inc. and Barrier Technology Corporation are, in that regard, totally dependent upon these for success in the business.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>6</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify>All employees are required to sign a Confidentiality Agreement that incorporates a &#147;do not compete clause&#148;. &nbsp;As these clauses pertain to Barrier&#146;s employees at the US operations, they have been drafted to conform to the strictest interpretation under Minnesota law.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Employees</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>As of 8/25/2016, the Company had 30 full-time employees, 6 full-time temporary, 2 full time Executive Officers and 1 part-time Corporate Secretary. &nbsp;As of 6/30/2016, the Company had 28 full-time employees, 6 full-time temporary employees, 2 full-time Executive Officers and 1 part-time Corporate Secretary. &nbsp;As of 6/30/2015, the Company had 23 full-time employees, two full-time Executive Officers and one part-time Corporate Secretary.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Dependency upon Customers</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><U>Fiscal 2016</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>During Fiscal 2016, the company&#146;s largest customer was LP&#174; Building Products (LP). &nbsp;LP is a customer that services the multifamily residential roof deck construction, wall assemblies, and structural insulated panels (SIPs) markets. &nbsp;LP purchased 79% of the 24,657,600 sq. ft. of Pyrotite&#174; products shipped in Fiscal 2016. &nbsp;LP is the largest producer of Oriented Strand Board (OSB) in the world and believes that Barrier&#146;s Pyrotite&#174; Technology will help them achieve their strategy of providing a number of value added OSB products to the building community. &nbsp;Through an exclusive supply agreement, LP has the exclusive right to sell Pyrotite&#174; treated panel products in North America in all markets other than the Commercial Modular (MuleHide Products, Inc./ABC Supply Company) Market, under their brand name LP&#174; FlameBlock&#174; Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing. &nbsp;Such markets include Multifamily Residential Roof Deck, Structural Wall Assemblies, and Structural Insulated Panels.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>LP&#174; FlameBlock&#174; is sold through wholesale distribution companies such as Boise, Cedar Creek, Curtis Lumber, Matheus Lumber, Taiga Building Products, Vandermeer Forest Products, Universal Forest Products, and Weyerhaeuser. &nbsp;The MidAtlantic Region market (MD-VA) remained the strongest region in these markets with 38% of total sales into these markets. &nbsp;Other regions in these markets include the South, the Midwest, the West and Canada. &nbsp;The building products distribution companies mentioned have a presence in all of these areas and are consistent FlameBlock customers throughout these geographies.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The second largest market for Pyrotite&#174; products was the commercial modular market which is serviced through MuleHide Products, Inc. &#147;Mulehide&#148; and parent company ABC Supply Company. &nbsp;Commercial modular sales accounted for 21% of total shipments in 2016. &nbsp;The FR Deck Panel is distributed through ABC Supply Company locations throughout the United States.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><U>Fiscal 2015</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>During Fiscal 2015, the company&#146;s largest customer was LP&#174; Building Products (LP). &nbsp;LP is a customer that services the multifamily residential roof deck construction, wall assemblies, and structural insulated panels (SIPs) markets. &nbsp;LP purchased 73% of the 21,624,100 sq. ft. of Pyrotite&#174; products shipped in Fiscal 2015. &nbsp;LP is the largest producer of Oriented Strand Board (OSB) in the world and believes that Barrier&#146;s Pyrotite&#174; Technology will help them achieve their strategy of providing a number of value added OSB products to the building community. &nbsp;Through an exclusive supply agreement, LP has the exclusive right to sell Pyrotite&#174; treated panel products in North America in all markets other than the Commercial Modular (MuleHide Products, Inc./ABC Supply Company) Market, under their brand name LP&#174; FlameBlock&#174; Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing. &nbsp;Such markets include Multifamily Residential Roof Deck, Structural Wall Assemblies, and Structural Insulated Panels.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>LP&#174; FlameBlock&#174; is sold through wholesale distribution companies such as Boise, Cedar Creek, Curtis Lumber, ProBuild, Reliable Wholesale, Taiga Building Products, Vandermeer Forest Products, Universal Forest Products, and Weekes Forest Products. &nbsp;The MidAtlantic Region market (MD-VA) remained the strongest region in these markets with 38% of total sales into these markets. &nbsp;Other regions in these markets include the South, the Midwest, the West and Canada. &nbsp;The building products distribution companies mentioned have a presence in all of these areas and are consistent FlameBlock customers throughout these geographies.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The second largest market for Pyrotite&#174; products was the commercial modular market which is serviced through MuleHide Products, Inc. &#147;Mulehide&#148; and parent company ABC Supply Company. &nbsp;Commercial modular sales accounted for 27% of total shipments in 2015. &nbsp;The FR Deck Panel is distributed through ABC Supply Company locations throughout the United States.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>7</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><B><U>1.D. &nbsp;Financial Information about Geographic Areas</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px">During Fiscal 2016 and 2015, all sales were in the United States.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>At 6/30/2016 and 6/30/2015: $5,442,573 and $4,908,641 of the assets were located in the United States and $15,344 and $16,244 were located in Canada, respectively.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc431114164"></A><P style="margin:0px"><B><U>ITEM 1A. &nbsp;RISK FACTORS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>In addition to the other information presented in this Annual Report, the following should be considered carefully in evaluating the Company and its business. &nbsp;This Annual Report contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. &nbsp;The Company's actual results may differ materially from results discussed in the forward-looking statements. &nbsp;Factors that might cause such a difference include those discussed below and elsewhere in this Annual Report.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><B>General Corporate Risks</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Investors may be disadvantaged because the Company is incorporated in Canada, which has different laws.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The articles/by-laws and the laws of Canada are different from those typical in the United States. &nbsp;The typical rights of investors in Canadian companies differ modestly from those in the United States. &nbsp;Such differences may cause investors legal difficulties.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>U.S. investors may not be able to enforce their civil liabilities against the Company or its directors, controlling persons and officers.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>It may be difficult to bring and enforce suits against the Company. &nbsp;The Company is a corporation incorporated under the laws of the British Columbia, Canada. &nbsp;A majority of the Company's directors are resident outside the United States, and all or substantial portions of their assets are located outside of the United States. &nbsp;As a result, it may be difficult for U.S. holders of the Company&#146;s common shares to effect service of process on these persons within the United States or to realize in the United States upon judgments rendered against them. &nbsp;In addition, a shareholder should not assume that the courts of Canada (i) would enforce judgments of U.S. courts obtained in actions against the Company or such persons predicated upon the civil liability provisions of the U.S. federal securities laws or other laws of the United States, or (ii) would enforce, in original actions, liabilities against us or such persons predicated upon the U.S. federal securities laws or other laws of the United States.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Passive Foreign Investment Company (&#147;PFIC&#148;) designation could lead to an adverse tax situation for U.S. investors.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>U.S. investors in the Company could be subject to U.S. taxation at possibly adverse or higher rates and under a system that might be more complicated and unfamiliar to them. &nbsp;For example, a U.S investor might be subject to special tax rules with respect to any &#147;excess distribution&#148; received and any gain realized from a sale or other disposition (including a pledge) of that holder's shares. &nbsp;Distributions a U.S. investor receives in a taxable year that are greater than 125% of the average annual distributions received during the shorter of the three preceding taxable years or the holder's holding period for the shares will be treated as excess distributions. &nbsp;For example, under certain circumstances, a U.S. investor who is an individual might be subject to information reporting requirements and backup withholding, currently at a 28% rate, on dividends received on common shares. &nbsp;If a U.S. Holder holds shares in any year in which the Company is a PFIC, that holder might be required to file Internal Revenue Service Form 8621.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><B>Risks Relating to Financial Condition</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>The Company has accumulated losses since inception.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Since inception through June 30, 2016, the Company has an accumulated deficit of ($13,184,459). &nbsp;In addition, our operating results in the future may be subject to fluctuations due to many factors not within our control, such as the unpredictability of when customers will order products, the size of customers' orders, the demand for our products, the level of competition or general economic conditions. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>The Company has strong net income this fiscal year, however, the Company&#146;s prior history of losses could require the need for additional, financings and related problems if net income doesn&#146;t continue.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company had positive net income this fiscal year: $317,005 FY2016 and net income of $701,581 in FY2015. &nbsp;The Company may require additional funding to meet its long-term business objectives, if the Company isn&#146;t able to continue the current trend of positive operating income. &nbsp;Capital may be needed to expand manufacturing capacity and marketing of the Company&#146;s products. &nbsp;The Company may not be able to obtain additional financing on reasonable terms, or at all. &nbsp;If equity financing is required, then such financings could result in significant dilution to existing </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>8</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify>shareholders. &nbsp;If the Company is unable to obtain sufficient financing, the Company might have to dramatically slow marketing efforts and/or lose control of its products. &nbsp;The Company has historically obtained the preponderance of its financing through the issuance of equity. &nbsp;There is a limit of 100,000,000 authorized common shares. &nbsp;The Company has no current plans to obtain financing through means other than equity financing and/or loans. &nbsp;The potential need for external financings could result in losses of investment value.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>The Company&#146;s need for additional financing to expand production and conduct marketing efforts could lead to the Company&#146;s inability to continue generating material sales revenue.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company develops, manufactures, and markets proprietary fire resistant building materials designed to help protect people and property from the destruction of fire. Additional amounts of financing may be required to facilitate corporate operational growth and to expand marketing efforts on a short-term basis. &nbsp;Conventional bank financing was originally established at a local bank for up to $1,000,000 in the form of a revolving line of credit. In July 2008, the terms of the existing revolving bank facility of $1,000,000 were modified to be comprised of a $500,000 capital loan being amortized by the bank over a 10-year period and which is secured by building, property and equipment and a $500,000 credit facility as an operating line of credit at 7.5%. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August 2010, the line of credit was amended to include a reduced limit of $250,000, and was extended until September 1, 2011 at a reduced interest rate of 6.75%. &nbsp;In December 2011, Barrier negotiated a term bank loan facility in the amount of $450,000 bearing interest at 6.25% and collateralized by a security interest in inventory, accounts receivable, equipment and all intangibles of the Company as well as an assignment of the building lease. The facility was being amortized over 4 years with fixed monthly blended payments of principal and interest totaling $6,800 with a balloon payment due on January 1, 2016. &nbsp;This facility was paid in full during the reporting period. By a promissory note agreement dated June 23, 2016 the Company has arranged for credit facilities with Farmers State Bank of Watkins which allows the Company to be advanced up to $500,000 under the terms of the promissory note agreement. Advances will bear interest at 5.0% per annum and will be repayable in installments of accrued interest beginning June 23, 2016 with the entire unpaid Principal and interest to be repaid on June 23, 2017. &nbsp;The balance at June 30, 2016 was $0.00. &nbsp;Advances are collateralized by a security interest on inventory, accounts receivable, equipment and all intangibles of the Company as well as an assignment of the building lease.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>The Company competes with other building materials companies that have similar operations, and many such competitor companies have operations and financial resources and industry experience far greater than those of the Company.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Even if the Company maintains a successful marketing program, the Company will still be subject to competition from much larger and financially stronger competitors and such competition may materially adversely affect the Company&#146;s financial performance. &nbsp;Also, the Company&#146;s need to acquire inventory will require additional financial resources.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>The Company relies on reliable and competitively priced suppliers. </U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier relies on key relationships with industry leaders to maintain its position in the market place. &nbsp;Barrier is dependent upon suppliers to provide key elements of production at critical times at reasonable prices. &nbsp;While the majority of these materials are readily available and abundant, without quality suppliers providing reasonable terms of sales, Barrier would not be able to stay in business: there would be no operating or working goods of production to use in the manufacturing process.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><B>Risks Relating to Management and Specific Operations</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>The Company&#146;s Articles/By-Laws contain provisions indemnifying its officers and directors against all costs, charges and expenses incurred by them.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company&#146;s Articles/By-Laws contain provisions that state, subject to applicable law, the Company shall indemnify every director or officer of the Company, subject to the limitations of the British Columbia Corporations Act, against all losses or liabilities that the Company&#146;s director or officer may sustain or incur in the execution of their duties. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s Articles/By-Laws further state that no director of officer shall be liable for any loss, damage or misfortune that may happen to, or be incurred by the Company in the execution of their duties if they acted honestly and in good faith with a view to the best interests of the Company. &nbsp;Such limitations on liability may reduce the likelihood of litigation against the Company&#146;s officers and directors and may discourage or deter its shareholders from suing the Company&#146;s officers and directors based upon breaches of their duties to the Company, though such an action, if successful, might otherwise benefit the Company and its shareholders.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>9</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify><B><U>Key management employees may fail to properly carry out their duties or may leave which could negatively impact corporate operations and/or stock pricing.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier is relatively &#147;thin&#148; in its management team. &nbsp;&nbsp;Barrier has intentionally kept the number of middle and upper management at a minimum in an effort to conserve financial resources. &nbsp;As the company grows it will be essential to have new talent emerging to help provide leadership in the factories of production and in the market place to introduce the products to new markets: &nbsp;both in geography and in use. &nbsp;As long as the management team is thin, the impact of losing a key player is very large.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>While developing, manufacturing, and marketing proprietary fire resistant building materials designed to help protect people and property from the destruction of fire, the nature of the Company&#146;s business, its ability to develop a successful sales force, and to develop a competitive edge in the marketplace, depends, in large part, on its ability to attract and maintain qualified key management personnel. &nbsp;Competition for such personnel is intense and the Company may not be able to attract and retain such personnel. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s growth will depend on the efforts of its Directors (David Corcoran, Michael Huddy, and Victor Yates) and its Senior Management. &nbsp;President/CEO/Director, Michael Huddy, and CFO, Melissa McElwee, work for the Company on a full-time basis. &nbsp;The Corporate Secretary, Lindsey Nauen works for the Company on a part-time basis. &nbsp;The Company carries no key-man insurance and there are no written agreements with them.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-19.2px" align=center><B>Risks Relating to Sales Environment</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier&#146;s business is directly related to housing/building starts in the United States. &nbsp;Any factor resulting in a slowdown of economic activity, especially those that result in an increase in interest rates will have a negative impact on Barrier&#146;s business. &nbsp;New housing starts in the U.S. continue to be on the rise. &nbsp;The U.S. Census Bureau reported 1,211,000 new housing starts in July 2016 (adjusted on an annual basis). July's numbers were 2.1 percent higher than the June 2016 estimate of 1,186,000 and 5.6 percent higher than the July 2015 annually adjusted rate of 1,147,000. &nbsp;There continues to be a risk that the economy is not yet stable enough to support long term improvements in new housing starts. &nbsp;If housing growth becomes unstable, sales of Pyrotite&#174; products could be negatively impacted or unpredictable.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-19.2px" align=center><B>Risks Relating to the Company&#146;s Common Stock</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Principal stockholders, officers and directors have substantial control regarding stock ownership; this concentration could lead to conflicts of interest and difficulties in the &#147;public&#148; investors effecting corporate changes, and could adversely affect the Company&#146;s stock prices.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company&#146;s Senior Management, Directors and greater-than-five-percent stockholders (and their affiliates), acting together, hold approximately 28% of the shares of the Company, on a diluted basis, and have the ability to control substantially all matters submitted to the Company&#146;s stockholders for approval (including the election and removal of directors and any merger, consolidation or sale of all or substantially all of the Company&#146;s assets) and to control the Company&#146;s management and affairs. &nbsp;Accordingly, this concentration of ownership may have the effect of delaying, deferring or preventing a change in control of the Company, impeding a merger, consolidation, takeover or other business combination involving the Company or discouraging a potential acquirer from making a tender offer or otherwise attempting to obtain control of the Company, which in turn could materially adversely affect the market price of the Company&#146;s stock.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Employee/Director/Consultant stock options could lead to greater concentration of stock ownership among insiders and could lead to dilution of stock ownership which could lead to depressed stock prices.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Because the success of the Company is highly dependent upon its respective employees, the Company has granted to some or all of its key employees, Directors and consultants options to purchase common shares as non-cash incentives. &nbsp;To the extent that significant numbers of such options may be granted and exercised, the interests of the other stockholders of the Company may be diluted causing possible loss of investment value.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>The Company has never declared or paid cash dividends on its common shares and does not anticipate doing so in the foreseeable future.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>There can be no assurance that the Company&#146;s Board of Directors will ever declare cash dividends, which action is exclusively within its discretion. &nbsp;Investors cannot expect to receive a dividend on the Company&#146;s common shares in the foreseeable future, if at all.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Low stock market prices and volume volatility for the Company&#146;s common shares create a risk that investors might not be able to effect purchases/sales at prices that accurately reflect corporate value.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>10</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify>The market for the common shares of the Company on the OTC Bulletin Board in the United States may be highly volatile for reasons both related to the performance of the Company or events pertaining to the industry (i.e., price fluctuation/technological change/new competitor) as well as factors unrelated to the Company or its industry. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s common shares can be expected to be subject to volatility in both price and volume arising from market expectations. &nbsp;Stockholders of the Company may be unable to sell significant quantities of common shares in the public trading markets without a significant reduction in the price of the common shares.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Broker-Dealers may be discouraged from effecting transactions in the Company&#146;s common shares because they are subject to the penny stock rules.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Rules 15g-1 through 15g-9 promulgated under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, impose sales practice and disclosure requirements on NASD broker-dealers who make a market in &#147;penny stock&#148;. &nbsp;A penny stock generally includes any non-NASDAQ equity security that has a market price of less than $5.00 per share. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s shares are quoted on the OTC Bulletin Board in the United States and the TSX Venture Exchange in Canada. &nbsp;The additional sales practice and disclosure requirements imposed upon broker-dealers may discourage broker-dealers from effecting transactions in the Company&#146;s shares, which could severely limit the market liquidity of the shares and impede the sale of the Company&#146;s shares in the secondary market.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Under the penny stock regulations, a broker-dealer selling penny stock to anyone other than an established customer or &#147;accredited investor&#148; (generally, an individual with net worth in excess of $1,000,000 or an annual income exceeding $200,000, or $300,000 together with his or her spouse) must make a special suitability determination for the purchaser and must receive the purchaser's written consent to the transaction prior to sale, unless the broker-dealer or the transaction is otherwise exempt.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>In addition, the penny stock regulations require the broker-dealer to deliver, prior to any transaction involving a penny stock, a disclosure schedule prepared by the US SEC relating to the penny stock market, unless the broker-dealer or the transaction is otherwise exempt. &nbsp;A broker-dealer is also required to disclose commissions payable to the broker-dealer and the registered representative and current quotations for the securities. &nbsp;Finally, a broker-dealer is required to send monthly statements disclosing recent price information with respect to the penny stock held in a customer's account and information with respect to the limited market in penny stocks.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc431114165"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 1B. &nbsp;UNRESOLVED STAFF COMMENTS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px">None</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>11</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc431114166"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 2. &nbsp;DESCRIPTION OF PROPERTY</U></B> &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company&#146;s operating and manufacturing facilities, along with executive offices, are located in leased premises at 510 Fourth Street North, Watkins, Minnesota. &nbsp;The Company entered into a 20-year capital lease in 1995. &nbsp;The lease allowed the Company to purchase the facility for a small &#147;transfer fee&#148; once the 20-year lease was up and the industrial development bonds the City of Watkins issued to fund the project are paid in full. &nbsp;During the reporting period, the capital lease for the manufacturing plant and property was paid in full. &nbsp;Barrier has received the deed to the property.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company&#146;s manufacturing complex consists of two manufacturing lines housed in the main building. &nbsp;A 2,500 square-foot office is located in the front of this building. &nbsp;To the immediate east of the main drive, three storage buildings (90&#146; x 60&#146;, 106&#146; x 60&#146;, and 106&#146;x60&#146;) allow for short-term storage of materials and products.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The earlier of the two production lines, our spray technology line, is housed nearest the offices and occupies approximately 22,000 sq. ft. of space. &nbsp;This line is primarily used for panels larger than 4&#146; x 8&#146; or for production not suited for the highly automated standard production line, including plywood. &nbsp;The mix for this line is produced in batches and fed through a reciprocating spray apparatus on to the panels. &nbsp;The fiberglass is supplied as roving and automatically chopped as it is applied to the panels. &nbsp;An infra-red oven supplies the energy to accelerate the cure of the coating; space is provided for the panels to be stacked. &nbsp;Specialty panels can be stacked in custom designed racks if required. The designed capacity from this line is 8MM board feet per shift. &nbsp;We are currently running two shifts on this line.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The newer of the two lines, our automated line, is housed in the extension added to the main building in 2004. &nbsp;This portion of the building is 15,000 sq. feet and houses a completely separate line. &nbsp;This line runs at 20 feet per minute and is capable of producing over 20MM board feet per shift annually when running at 100% efficiency. &nbsp;We are currently running this line on a shift and a half and could quickly increase our capacity to meet market demand by adding an additional half shift. &nbsp;Automation efficiencies on this line cover: unstacking and restacking of panels; use of automated Pyrotite coating equipment, a computer controlled mixing area; automatic panel weight information fed back continuously to the operators; and a custom panel curing system. &nbsp;This line produces panels of much higher, consistent quality than the older line, at a much more marketable cost point.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>In August 2015, it was announced that a second manufacturing line will be added at LP&#146;s existing Clarke County, Alabama location. &nbsp;That manufacturing line is expected to come on line later in 2016. Future growth plans may include plant(s) modeled after this new line, placed strategically near markets of prime opportunity; built either by Barrier or with licensed partners. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Regardless of which line is used, the production process for the Pyrotite&#174; technology contains no hazardous or controlled substances that could raise environmental concerns. &nbsp;&nbsp;The majority of the materials used in the production of Pyrotite&#174; are naturally occurring and are therefore accepted at local land-fills. &nbsp;Use and handling instructions for the Company&#146;s finished products are no more stringent than those required for handling other natural wood based building products.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc431114167"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 3. &nbsp;LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Directors and the management of the Company know of no material, active or pending, legal proceedings against them; nor is the Company involved as a plaintiff in any material proceeding or pending litigation.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Directors and the management of the Company know of no active or pending proceedings against anyone that might materially adversely affect an interest of the Company.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc431114168"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 4. &nbsp;MINE SAFETY DISCLOSURES</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px">Not applicable</P>
<A NAME="_Toc431114169"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-size:12pt" align=center><B>PART II</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc431114170"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 5. &nbsp;MARKET FOR COMMON EQUITY AND RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Market Information</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company's common shares began trading on the TSX Venture Exchange (formerly the Canadian Venture Exchange) in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, under its former name Barrier Technology Inc. in September 1986. &nbsp;The current stock symbol is &#147;IBH.V&#148;. &nbsp;The CUSIP number is #458968-10-4.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company&#146;s common shares began trading on the OTC Bulletin Board in August 2002. &nbsp;The current stock symbol is IBTGF.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>12</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Holders</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company's common shares are issued in registered form and the following information is taken from the records of Computershare (located in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada), the registrar and transfer agent for the common shares.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>On 10/23/2015, the Company&#146;s shareholders&#146; list showed 47,807,426 common shares outstanding and 139 registered shareholders with: 7,513,669 shares owned by 38 registered shareholders/depositories resident in Canada, 16% of the total; 40,293,657 shares owned by 100 registered shareholders/depositories resident in the United States; and 100 shares owned by one shareholder in one other country.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Based on this research and other research into the indirect holdings of other financial institutions, the Company believes that it has approximately 6000 beneficial owners of its common shares.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Dividends</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company has not declared any dividends since incorporation and does not anticipate that it will do so in the foreseeable future. &nbsp;The present policy of the Company is to retain future earnings for use in its operations and expansion of its business. &nbsp;There are no restrictions that limit the ability of the Company to pay dividends on common equity or that are likely to do so in the future.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:19.2px">Fiscal 2011: 40,000 units at US$0.09 per unit = US$3,600</P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>

<P style="margin:0px" align=center>14</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc431114172"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 7. &nbsp;MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The SEC defines critical accounting policies as those that are, in management's view, important to the portrayal of the Company&#146;s financial condition and results of operations and require management's judgment. &nbsp;The discussion and analysis of the financial condition and results of operations is based on the audited consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (&quot;U.S. GAAP&quot;). &nbsp;The preparation of these financial statements requires the Company to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses. &nbsp;Management bases its estimates on experience and on various assumptions that it believes are reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. &nbsp;Actual results may differ from those estimates. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s critical accounting policies include:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><U>Revenue Recognition</U></P>
<P style="margin-top:6.667px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify>The Company recognizes revenue in accordance with Financial Accounting Standards Board&#146;s (&#147;FASB&#148;) Accounting Standards Codification (&#147;ASC&#148;) 605, &#147;Revenue Recognition&#148;, which requires that: (i) persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, (ii) delivery has occurred, (iii) the sales price is fixed and determinable, and (iv) collection is reasonably assured. The Company recognizes revenue when the building supplies have been shipped.</P>
<P style="margin-top:6.667px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify>Revenue for LP&#174; FlameBlock Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing includes only the charges for treatment services, not the underlying OSB substrate or outbound freight as the customer supplies its own OSB Substrate and contracts for its own outgoing freight.</P>
<P style="margin-top:6.667px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify>The Company periodically enters into arrangements that contain multiple deliverable elements requiring an evaluation of each deliverable to determine whether it represents a separate unit of accounting. Each delivered item constitutes a separate unit of accounting when it has stand-alone value to the customer obligating the Company to determine a selling price for each deliverable. </P>
<P style="margin-top:6.667px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify><I>License Fees</I></P>
<P style="margin-top:6.667px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify>License fees are based on sales of licenses to third parties. &nbsp;Revenue from up-front license fees and milestones payments is recognized as performance occurs and the respective obligations are completed. &nbsp;Prior to the completion of performance obligations, up-front payments are recorded as deferred revenue.</P>
<P style="margin-top:6.667px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify><I>Royalty Revenue</I></P>
<P style="margin-top:6.667px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify>Royalty revenue from sales of our products is generally recognized when received or earned in accordance with the terms of the license fee agreements. &nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:6.667px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify>In accordance with the terms of the agreement, commencing on the first anniversary date of the agreement, the licensee will commence paying royalties to the Company for the product it manufactures and sells. &nbsp;Licence fees are recognized as earned in accordance with the terms of the agreement when the license fees can be reasonably estimated and collectability is reasonably assured<FONT style="font-family:'inherit,Times New Roman'">.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><U>Impairment of Long-Lived Assets</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company reviews the recoverability of its long-lived assets whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable. &nbsp;The estimated future cash flows are based upon, among other things, assumptions about future operating performance, and may differ from actual cash flows. &nbsp;Long-lived assets evaluated for impairment are grouped with other assets to the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of other groups of assets and liabilities. &nbsp;If the sum of the projected undiscounted cash flows (excluding interest) is less than the carrying value of the assets, the assets will be written down to the estimated fair value in the period in which the determination is made.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><U>Stock-based Compensation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The company accounts for all stock-based payments and awards under the fair value based method.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Stock-based payments to non-employees are measured at the fair value of the consideration received, or the fair value of the equity instruments issued, or liabilities incurred, whichever is more reliably measurable. &nbsp;The fair value of stock-based payments to non-employees is periodically re-measured until the counterparty performance is complete, and any change therein is recognized over the vesting period of the award and in the same manner as if the Company had paid cash instead of aping with or using equity based instruments. &nbsp;The cost of the stock-based payments to non-employees that is fully vested and non-forfeitable as at the grant date is measured and recognized at that date.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>15</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify>The Company accounts for the granting of share purchase options to employees using the fair value method whereby all awards to employees will be recorded at fair value on the date of the grant. &nbsp;The fair value of all share purchase options are expensed over their vesting period with a corresponding increase to additional capital surplus. &nbsp;Upon exercise of share purchase options, the consideration paid by the option holder, together with the amount previously recognized in additional paid-in capital is recorded as an increase to share capital.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company uses the binomial option pricing model to determine the fair value of all stock based awards classified as liabilities and the Black-Scholes option pricing model to calculate the fair value of share purchase options. &nbsp;Option pricing models require the input of highly subjective assumptions, include the expected price volatility. &nbsp;Changes in these assumptions can materially affect the fair value estimate.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Equity Financing Timeline</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px">Fiscal 2011: &nbsp;40,000 units at US$0.09 per unit = US$3,600</P>
<P style="margin:0px">Fiscal 2012: &nbsp;None</P>
<P style="margin:0px">Fiscal 2013: &nbsp;None</P>
<P style="margin:0px">Fiscal 2014: &nbsp;100,000 units at US$0.097 per unit = US$9,700</P>
<P style="margin:0px">Fiscal 2015: &nbsp;3,252,500 units at US $0.10 per unit = US$325,250</P>
<P style="margin:0px">Fiscal 2016: &nbsp;None</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Fiscal 2016 Ended 6/30/2016</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>International Barrier Technology Inc. (Barrier) manufactures and sells fire-rated building materials. Barrier&#146;s primary business is in the United States but through the development of distribution partnerships and manufacturing technology license agreements is successfully endeavoring to enter building products markets in Australia, Europe, and South America. Barrier possesses a proprietary fire resistive material technology (Pyrotite&#174;) and a patented manufacturing process that when applied to building materials their respective fire resistant properties are significantly enhanced. &nbsp;Many of the top multifamily and wood frame commercial builders in the United States utilize Barrier&#146;s fire-rated structural panels in areas where the building code requires the use of a fire-rated building panel.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier currently manufactures a private label fire rated sheathing product under contract for both LP<SUP>&#174; </SUP>Building Products, Inc. (LP) and MuleHide Products, Inc. (MuleHide). &nbsp;LP introduced a fire rated OSB trademarked LP<SUP>&#174;</SUP> Flameblock<SUP>&#174;</SUP> Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing (LP FlameBlock) in 2010 and MuleHide and parent company, ABC Supply Company, have been selling FR Deck Panel to commercial modular building manufacturers since 2004.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier&#146;s financial statements are filed with both the SEC (USA) and SEDAR (Canada) and are disclosed in US dollars utilizing US generally accepted accounting principles. &nbsp;Barrier&#146;s filings with the SEC consist of quarterly reviews financial statements on Form 10-Q and annual audited financial statements on Form 10-K. &nbsp;Barrier continues to file the above financial statements with SEDAR in Canada.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Sales</U> </B>revenue reported for the fiscal period ending June 30, 2016 was up 13% to $9,527,052 in comparison to $8,434,452 generated in the same fiscal period in 2015. Total sales volume, as measured by surface volume of product shipped, was 24,657,648 sq. ft.. &nbsp;This is a 14% increase from the 21,624,100 sq. ft. shipped during the previous year. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Shipments into the Residential Roof Deck, Wall Assembly, and Structural Insulated Panel Market Sectors (LP FlameBlock) during the fiscal year increased 21% over shipments in fiscal 2015. &nbsp;Sales into the Commercial Modular Market (FR Deck Panel) decreased 4% in comparison to the previous year. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The following is a summary of sales for the past two fiscal years ending June 30:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

</TD></TR>

</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px; padding-left:9.6px; padding-top:0px; padding-right:9.6px; padding-bottom:0px; border-bottom:3px double #000000" valign=bottom width=120><P style="margin:0px">&nbsp;$ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;8,471,952 </P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>16</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify>The fire resistance of I-Joists is a timely and important topic in North America&#146;s building environment at this time. &nbsp;Web stock material treated in Watkins is being used to assist in the development of a committed market demand for Pyrotite&#174; technology. &nbsp;Concurrently, plans and decisions for manufacturing or licensing the technology for production of treated I-Joist in the long-term are being developed and made. &nbsp;The negative impact I-Joist R&amp;D has on shipments has been diminishing as production techniques improve with experience.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier and LP conduct business guided by a Supply Agreement. &nbsp;&nbsp;In August 2015, the existing Supply Agreement was extended until December 31, 2019. &nbsp;In addition, in August 2015, Barrier granted a license to LP for the manufacture and distribution of Pyrotite<SUP>&#174;</SUP> products in a plant in Clarke County Alabama. This license agreement will provide an additional revenue stream for Barrier. &nbsp;LP held a ground breaking celebration in early January 2016 for the new FlameBlock OSB Sheathing line at their Clarke County Alabama location. &nbsp;The line is anticipated to be operational late 2016.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The relationship with LP has contributed to an increase in sales volume to record levels and Barrier anticipates that sales will continue to grow substantially through the sustained efforts of LP&#146;s sales and marketing team. &nbsp;Reported sales revenue for LP products, include only the charges for treatment services, not the underlying OSB substrate or outbound freight as LP supplies its own OSB substrate and contracts for its own outgoing freight. &nbsp;The &#147;pass through&#148; of the OSB substrate and freight serves to lower reported &#147;top line&#148; sales revenue, but not gross profits since margins on substrate and freight have historically been restricted to handling costs only to help keep prices competitive. &nbsp;For the Commercial Modular market, Barrier purchases OSB from local distributors and invoices the cost of the substrate and outgoing freight to the customer, therefore the cost of the substrate and freight is included in revenue for Commercial Modular shipments.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>License fee royalties </U></B>for the period increased to $87,500 from $37,500. &nbsp;This is due to increased manufacturing and license fees receivable from Barrier&#146;s license agreement in the European Union. &nbsp;Barrier&#146;s new license agreement in the southern U.S. will also generate revenue in this category in future reporting periods.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Gross profit</U></B> for the fiscal period was $1,427,755 vs. $1,791,376 in the previous year. The gross margin, as a percentage of sales revenue, decreased to 15% in the current fiscal year from 21% in the prior year. &nbsp;In the near term, gross margins are anticipated to improve based on continued gains in production efficiency with I-Joist and the addition of an additional partial shift. &nbsp;Capacity limitations at the current manufacturing facility in Watkins, Minnesota, however, are being approached and further non-marginal improvement in scale efficiency will be delayed until additional production capacity is added. &nbsp;Additional manufacturing capacity through the addition of a FlameBlock line in Clarke County Alabama is anticipated by late 2016. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Cost of sales</U> </B>increased to $8,186,797 in 2016 from $6,680,576 in Fiscal 2015. &nbsp;The increase is attributable to the increase in volume produced and the manufacture of fire-rated I-Joist material. &nbsp;Manufacturing efficiency as measured by the average cost per square foot of production was $0.33 in comparison to $0.31 during the prior year fiscal reporting period.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Substrate cost and materials/labor were the major expenses in this category. &nbsp;Substrate accounted for $1,453,606 for the fiscal year versus $1,311,514 in the same period last year. Materials and labor accounted for an additional $5,230,859 in the twelve month period in 2016 versus $3,956,543 in 2015.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Depreciation on plant and equipment is included in cost of sales category. Depreciation, which has non-cash impact on Barrier&#146;s actual cash flow, increased slightly year-to-date from $337,777 in 2015 to $342,734. &nbsp;The expense reflects scheduled depreciation of the newer manufacturing line equipment and building expansion. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Administrative expenses</U></B> for Fiscal 2016 increased to $1,083,256 from $1,016,820 in the prior year. &nbsp;The administrative costs per sq. ft. were $0.044 for the fiscal year which was lower than the $0.047 reported in Fiscal 2015. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Accounting and Audit Fees</U></B> increased from $77,693 to $86,498. &nbsp;A significant portion of the cost for accounting services are involved with the annual audit of Barrier&#146;s fiscal year-end financial statements. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Insurance costs</U></B> have increased from $85,438 to $87,082. &nbsp;The difference is due to annually adjusted premiums based on larger sales volume. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Legal fees</U></B> decreased from $89,763 in Fiscal 2015 to $57,813 in Fiscal 2016. &nbsp;Legal fees were expended on activities in support of developing strategic partners and technology licensees, the year-end Annual General Meeting, as well as in monitoring and protecting Pyrotite&#174; patents and trademarks. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>17</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify>Barrier has two US patents, a patent in Australia, and a patent in Canada. These patents protect the manufacturing and process technology utilized in the production of fire-rated sheathing products utilizing Pyrotite&#174;. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Sales, marketing, and investor relations</U></B> expenses decreased from $43,484 to $34,481 for the year. During the year, there were sales trips directly related to the expansion of product markets.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier&#146;s cost for sales and marketing will remain at relatively low levels compared to sales volumes as our partners, LP and MuleHide Products/ABC Supply Co., perform the majority of those functions themselves. &nbsp;Barrier remains active in a support role by providing necessary technical sales support but most of the day to day market and sales development activities are already being performed by the capable sales and marketing staff of LP and MuleHide Products/ABC Supply Co. resulting in improved sales but also lower costs for Barrier.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Wages and management fees</U></B> increased to $705,210 from $605,511. &nbsp;The increase in wages and management fees is attributed to Board of Director remuneration for the execution of the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation Technology License Agreement and accrual of the annual $15,000 Board of Director compensation for each of the periods ending June 30, 2015 and June 30, 2016 for each of the directors.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Operating Income</U> </B>of $344,499 is being reported for the fiscal period ending June 30, 2016, vs. $774,556 that was reported for the same period last year.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The decline in operating income is a result of lower efficiencies during the first test period and production of manufacturing I-Joist material. &nbsp;There were also substantial costs associated with finding and training labor to manufacture an additional partial shift of production on our second shift on the automated line. &nbsp;Its Barrier&#146;s fundamental belief that increased sales volume coupled with an intense focus on manufacturing efficiency is the best pathway to long-term profitability and expansion. &nbsp;New products will be the driver for such long-term expansion in sales.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Other items </U></B>include income and costs not directly related to business operations. &nbsp;Other income items reported during the fiscal year herein includes interest/other income of $12,256. &nbsp;To compare, for the same reporting period last year there was interest/other income of $1,129. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Interest on Long Term Debt has decreased from $54,417 to $31,750 for the 12-month reporting period as a result of larger principal payments as long term debt ages. &nbsp;During the reporting period, the capital lease for the manufacturing plant and property was paid in full. &nbsp;Barrier has received the deed to the property.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Income taxes </U></B>There was a deferred income tax expense of $8,000 resulting from the recognition of income tax assets in the amount of $266,000 related to the Company&#146;s net operating losses offset by the recognition of a deferred tax liability in respect of a basis difference in the Company&#146;s U.S. capital assets in the amount of $274,000. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Net Income.</U> &nbsp;</B>Net income of $317,005 is being reported for the fiscal period ending June 30, 2016, whereas in the same period in 2015, net income of $701,581 was reported. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier remains focused on cutting costs and improving efficiencies wherever it can. &nbsp;This includes operating the manufacturing line with maximum efficiency. Keeping a vigilant handle on costs will help keep operational costs as low as possible and enable financial improvements to continue and at lower volumes than previously possible.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Summary of Quarterly Results.</U></B> &nbsp;The following is a summary of the Company&#146;s financial results for the nine most recently completed quarters:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
